sen.j: 松尾大社（まつのおたいしゃ）は、京都市西京区にある神社である。
sen.e: Matsunoo-taisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Nishigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Matsunoo-taisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Nishigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Matsunoo-taisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Nishigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大）、二十二社の一社で、旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: It was listed in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki and was ranked as a Kanpei Taisha under the old shrine classification system.
It was listed in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki and was ranked as a Kanpei Taisha under the old shrine classification system.

It was listed in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki and was one of the Twenty-Two Shrines and was ranked as a Kanpei Taisha (large-scale state shrine) under the old shrine classification system.
sen.cmt: (large-scale state shrine)補足was one of the Twenty-Two Shrines補足

sen.j: 旧称松尾神社。
sen.e: The shrine was formerly named Matsunoo-jinja Shrine.
The shrine was formerly named Matsunoo-jinja Shrine.
The shrine was formerly named Matsunoo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 大山咋神と中津島姫命を祀る。
sen.e: The deities Oyamakuino-kami and Nakatsushimahimeno-mikoto are enshrined.
The deities Oyamakuino-kami and Nakatsushimahimeno-mikoto are enshrined.
The deities Oyamakuino-kami and Nakatsushimahimeno-mikoto are enshrined.

sen.j: 中津島姫命はイチキシマヒメの別名とされるが、異説もある。
sen.e: It is thought that Nakatsushimahimeno-mikoto is an alternative name for Ichikishimahime but there are alternative theories.
It is thought that Nakatsushimahimeno-mikoto is an alternative name for Ichikishimahime but there are alternative theories.
It is thought that Nakatsushimahimeno-mikoto is an alternative name for Ichikishimahime but there are alternative theories.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 当社の背後の松尾山 (京都府)(223m)に古社地があり、山頂に近い大杉谷に磐座とされる巨石がある。
sen.e: The old site of Matsunoo-taisha Shrine is on Mt. Matsuo (Kyoto Prefecture) (223m), located to its rear, and there is a large rock that is thought to be an iwakura (a rock where a kami is invited to descend) in Osugidani Valley near to the summit.

The old site of Matsunoo-taisha Shrine is on Mt. Matsuo (Kyoto Prefecture) (223m), located to its rear, and there is a large rock that is thought to be an iwakura (a rock where a kami is invited to descend) in Osugidani Valley near to the summit.

The old site of Matsunoo-taisha Shrine is on Mt. Matsuo (Kyoto Prefecture) (223 m), located to its rear, and there is a large rock that is thought to be an iwakura (a rock where a kami is invited to descend) in Osugidani Valley near to the summit.

sen.j: 5世紀ごろ、渡来人の秦氏が山城国一帯に居住し、松尾山の神（大山咋神）を氏神とした。
sen.e: In the 5th century, The Hata clan immigrated to Japan where they settled in Yamashiro Province and took the Mt. Matsuo kami (Oyamakuino-kami) as their ujigami (guardian deity).
In the 5th century, The Hata clan immigrated to Japan where they settled in Yamashiro Province and took the Mt. Matsuo kami (Oyamakuino-kami) as their ujigami (guardian deity).
In the 5th century, the Hata clan immigrated to Japan where they settled in Yamashiro Province and took the Mt. Matsuo kami (Oyamakuino-kami) as their ujigami (guardian deity).

sen.j: 大山咋神については、『古事記』に「亦の名は山末之大主神。
sen.e: From the description given in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) stating that 'Oyamakuino-kami is 'another name for Yamasueno Onushino Kami.
sen.cmt: 「亦の名は山末之大主神→"another name is Yamasueno Onushino Kami"
sen.e: From the description given in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) stating that 'Oyamakuino-kami is 'another name for Yamasueno Onushino Kami.
From the description given in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) stating that 'Oyamakuino-kami is another name for Yamasueno Onushino Kami.

sen.j: 此の神は近淡海国の日枝の山に坐し、亦葛野の松尾に坐して、鳴鏑を用つ神ぞ」と記されており、古事記が編纂されたころには有力な神とされていたことがわかる。
sen.e: The male kami resides at Hie-no-yama in Chikatsu Omi-no-kuni and Kazu-no-Matsunoom and uses a nari-kabura (singing arrow)', it is known that this deity was highly influential at the time that "Kojiki" was compiled.

The male kami resides at Hie-no-yama in Chikatsu Omi-no-kuni and Kazu-no-Matsunoom and uses a nari-kabura (singing arrow)', it is known that this deity was highly influential at the time that "Kojiki" was compiled.

The male kami resides at Hie-no-yama in Chikatsu Omi-no-kuni and Kazu-no-Matsunoo and uses a nari-kabura (singing arrow),' it is known that this deity was highly influential at the time that Kojiki was compiled.

sen.j: 大宝 (日本)元年（701年）、勅命により秦忌寸都理（はたのいみきとり）が現在地に社殿を造営し、山頂附近の磐座から神霊を移し、娘を斎女として奉仕させた。
sen.e: In the year 701, HATA no Imikitori constructed shrine buildings on the current site to which he brought divine spirits from the iwakura near the summit of the mountain, and allowed his daughter to serve as priestess.

In the year 701, HATA no Imikitori constructed shrine buildings on the current site to which he brought divine spirits from the iwakura near the summit of the mountain, and allowed his daughter to serve as priestess.

In the year 701, HATA no Imikitori constructed shrine buildings on the current site to which he brought divine spirits from the iwakura near the summit of the mountain, and allowed his daughter to serve as priestess.

sen.j: 以降、明治初期に神職の世襲が禁止されるまで、秦氏が当社の神職を務めた。
sen.e: Members of the Hata clan continued to serve as head priests at the shrine until hereditary Shinto priesthood was prohibited in the early Meiji era.
Members of the Hata clan continued to serve as head priests at the shrine until hereditary Shinto priesthood was prohibited in the early Meiji era.
Members of the Hata clan continued to serve as head priests at the shrine until hereditary Shinto priesthood was prohibited in the early Meiji period.

sen.j: 平安京遷都により、皇城鎮護の神として崇敬されるようになり、「賀茂神社の厳神、松尾の猛神」と並び称された。
sen.e: The relocation of the capital to the city to Heian-kyo made the kami enshrined at the shrine highly revered as a guardian of the imperial palace, and it became equal in status to the deity of Kamo-jinja Shrine.

The relocation of the capital to the city to Heian-kyo made the kami enshrined at the shrine highly revered as a guardian of the imperial palace, and it became equal in status to the deity of Kamo-jinja Shrine.

The relocation of the capital to the city to Heian-kyo made the kami enshrined at the shrine highly revered as a guardian of the imperial palace, and it became equal in status to the deity of Kamo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 『延喜式』では名神大社に列し、その後二十二社の一社ともなった。
sen.e: The shrine is classified as a Myojin Taisha (a grand shrine enshrines a high-ranked deity) in the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and it later became one of the Twenty-Two Shrines.
The shrine is classified as a Myojin Taisha (a grand shrine enshrines a high-ranked deity) in the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and it later became one of the Twenty-Two Shrines.
The shrine is classified as a Myojin Taisha (a grand shrine enshrines a high-ranked deity) in the "Engishiki" (procedures of the Engi era) and it later became one of the Twenty-Two Shrines.

sen.j: 近代社格制度のもと、明治4年（1871年）に松尾神社として官幣大社に列格し、戦後は別表神社となった。
sen.e: In 1871, the shrine was classified as a Kanpei Taisha under the former modern shrine classification system before becoming a Beppyo Jinja after the Second World War.
In 1871, the shrine was classified as a Kanpei Taisha under the former modern shrine classification system before becoming a Beppyo Jinja after the Second World War.
In 1871, the shrine was classified as a Kanpei Taisha under the former modern shrine classification system before becoming a Beppyo Jinja (Shrines on the Special List) after the Second World War.

sen.j: 昭和25年（1950年）に松尾大社に改称した。
sen.e: The name of the shrine was changed to Matsunoo-taisha Shrine in 1950.
The name of the shrine was changed to Matsunoo-taisha Shrine in 1950.
The name of the shrine was changed to Matsunoo-taisha Shrine in 1950.

sen.j: 秦氏は酒造の技術も日本に伝えたことから、中世以降、松尾神は酒造の神としても信仰されるようになった。
sen.e: Since the middle ages, the deity at Matsunoo-taisha Shrine has been worshipped as the god of rice-wine production as it was the Hata clan that brought rice-wine brewing technology to Japan.
Since the middle ages, the deity at Matsunoo-taisha Shrine has been worshipped as the god of rice-wine production as it was the Hata clan that brought rice-wine brewing technology to Japan.
Since the middle ages, the deity at Matsunoo-taisha Shrine has been worshipped as the god of rice-wine production as it was the Hata clan that brought rice-wine brewing technology to Japan.

sen.j: 社殿
sen.e: Shrine Buildings
Shrine Buildings
Shrine buildings

sen.j: 本社と、摂末社の四大神・衣手・三宮・宗像（市杵島姫命）・櫟谷（いちたに、宗像三女神）・月読神社 (京都市)（ツクヨミ）の各社を併せて松尾七社という。
sen.e: The main shrine and its auxiliary/subsidiary shrines Shi-no-Ookami-jinja Shrine, Koromode-jinja Shrine, San-no-miya-jinja Shrine, Munakata-jinja Shrine (Ichikishimahimeno Mikoto), Ichitani-jinja Shrine (Ichitani, Munakata Sanjojin) and Tsukuyomi-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) are collectively known as the "Matsunoo Mana-sha" (lit. Seven Shrines of Matsunoo).

The main shrine and its auxiliary/subsidiary shrines Shi-no-Ookami-jinja Shrine, Koromode-jinja Shrine, San-no-miya-jinja Shrine, Munakata-jinja Shrine (Ichikishimahimeno Mikoto), Ichitani-jinja Shrine (Ichitani, Munakata Sanjojin) and Tsukuyomi-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) are collectively known as the "Matsunoo Mana-sha" (lit. Seven Shrines of Matsunoo).

The main shrine and its auxiliary/subsidiary shrines Shi-no-Okami-jinja Shrine, Koromode-jinja Shrine, San-no-miya-jinja Shrine, Munakata-jinja Shrine (Ichikishimahimeno Mikoto), Ichitani-jinja Shrine (Munakata Sanjojin) and Tsukuyomi-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) are collectively known as the "Matsunoo Nana-sha" (lit. Seven Shrines of Matsunoo).

sen.j: このうち月読神社と櫟谷神社（現在は宗像社と合祀されて櫟谷宗像神社）は式内社である。
sen.e: Of these, Tsukuyomi-jinja Shrine and Ichitani-jinja Shrine Shrine (now combined with Munakata-jinja Shrine and known as Ichitani Munakata-jinja Shrine) are listed in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

Of these, Tsukuyomi-jinja Shrine and Ichitani-jinja Shrine Shrine (now combined with Munakata-jinja Shrine and known as Ichitani Munakata-jinja Shrine) are listed in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

Of these, Tsukuyomi-jinja Shrine and Ichitani-jinja Shrine (now combined with Munakata-jinja Shrine and known as Ichitani Munakata-jinja Shrine) are listed in the Register of Deities of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

sen.j: 本殿
sen.e: Main Sanctuary
Main Sanctuary

sen.j: 屋根は松尾造りと呼ばれる両流造りの構造で、現在のものは応永11年(1397年)の建立である。
sen.e: The current building was constructed in 1397 and the roof features a form of the ryonagare-zukuri style (gable roof which has a long, flowing, curved roof lines on both the front and rear slopes) which is referred to as Matsunoo-zukuri.

The current building was constructed in 1397 and the roof features a form of the ryonagare-zukuri style (gable roof which has a long, flowing, curved roof lines on both the front and rear slopes) which is referred to as Matsunoo-zukuri.

sen.j: 木造神像 3躯（男神2、女神1）
sen.e: 3 wooden god statues (2 male and 1 female)
